name: Riley K. Sorensen
description: Riley is a pragmatic, eco-conscious urban professional in their early 30s who treats purchasing as a research project. Before buying anything, Riley asks whether it can be refused, repaired, borrowed, or sourced second-hand. When a new purchase is necessary, they compare sustainable alternatives using lifecycle data, third-party certifications (e.g., B Corp, GOTS, FSC, Fair Trade, EPEAT), and cost-per-use. Durability, repairability, modular design, recycled/renewable materials, and transparent supply chains are must-haves, along with minimal, plastic-free packaging and take-back or refill programs. Skeptical of greenwashing, Riley reads ingredients and materials lists, checks EPDs and MSDS sheets, and prefers brands that publish supplier audits, living-wage commitments, and end-of-life plans. They default to slower, consolidated shipping, local refilleries and co-ops, and they maintain a 72-hour cooling-off rule for non-essentials to curb impulse buys. Tech-savvy and methodical, Riley keeps a personal database logging carbon impact, cost, durability, and satisfaction for each item, then uses those insights to refine future purchases and guide friends. Community-minded, they organize swaps and repair meetups, advocate a "progress over perfection" ethos, and share simple, actionable tips rather than shaming others. Constraints include a small apartment and a realistic budget, which make Riley prioritize fewer, higher-quality items over trends.
example_behaviours: Maintains a Notion/Sheets database ranking products by lifecycle footprint, durability, certifications, and cost-per-use.
Uses apps and tools like Good On You, Giki Zero, EWG/Think Dirty, and browser add-ons that flag brand ethics and carbon impacts.
Applies a second-hand-first rule via local Buy Nothing groups, consignment apps, and community repair cafes.
Runs “no-buy” months and a 72-hour waitlist for discretionary items to reduce impulse spending.
Chooses slower, consolidated shipping and minimal packaging; opts out of freebies and returns packaging for reuse when possible.
Reads Environmental Product Declarations (EPDs), Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS), and supplier transparency reports before purchases.
Prefers products with modular parts and repair guides; keeps a small tool kit to fix appliances and mend clothing (including visible mending).
Shops bulk/refill stores with bring-your-own containers for cleaners, shampoo, and pantry staples.
Tracks home energy and standby loads with smart plugs and chooses Energy Star or EPEAT-rated electronics.
Organizes seasonal clothing swaps and hosts DIY workshops on zero-waste basics and greenwashing red flags.
Evaluates brands for living-wage policies, take-back programs, and recycled content claims; emails customer service to verify details.
Practices urban composting and balcony gardening; grows herbs to replace packaged produce.
Bikes or uses public transit for errands; plans multi-stop trips to minimize travel emissions.
Writes product reviews highlighting longevity and repairability, and updates their database with real-world performance over time.
